author: timbeiko
content:
But, some of them also don't have formal job postings. If you want to engage with them, I recommend looking on their Github repositories and working on `Good First Issues` as a way to build a relationship with the team. Again, here are a few examples:

- https://github.com/ethereum/go-ethereum/labels/good%20first%20issue
- https://github.com/sigp/lighthouse/labels/good%20first%20issue
- https://github.com/ChainSafe/lodestar/issues?q=is%3Aissue+is%3Aopen+label%3Ameta-goodfirstissue

author: timbeiko
content: Or, if there are generally things you think can be improved in clients, just proactively trying to help there can get you more involved with the team. That said, the risk there is what you think is high priority ends up not being high priority for them, so you need to have good judgement to do this ðŸ˜…  Right now, anything merge-related, even if it's just testing/QA is probably helpful to teams.
